title: The Inkwell
text:
The Inkwell is a 1994 <a href="romantic%20comedy">romantic comedy</a>-<a href="comedy-drama">drama</a> film, <a href="film%20director">directed</a> by <a href="Matty%20Rich">Matty Rich</a>. The film stars <a href="Larenz%20Tate">Larenz Tate</a>, <a href="Joe%20Morton">Joe Morton</a>, <a href="Suzzanne%20Douglass">Suzzanne Douglass</a>, <a href="Glynn%20Turman">Glynn Turman</a>, <a href="Jada%20Pinkett%20Smith">Jada Pinkett</a> and <a href="Vanessa%20Bell%20Calloway">Vanessa Bell Calloway</a>.
Plot.
Set in the summer of 1976, the film follows the adventures of Drew Tate (<a href="Larenz%20Tate">Larenz Tate</a>), a 16-year-old from <a href="upstate%20New%20York">upstate New York</a>, when he and his family spend two weeks with affluent relatives on <a href="Martha%27s%20Vineyard">Martha's Vineyard</a>. Drew's parents, Kenny (<a href="Joe%20Morton">Joe Morton</a>) and Brenda (<a href="Suzzanne%20Douglass">Suzzanne Douglass</a>), worry that their son is emotionally disturbed. His favorite companion is a doll, in which he names Iago (after the character in the Shakespeare classic <a href="Othello">Othello</a>), with which he engages in animated conversations. They also fear that a fire he accidentally set in the family garage foreshadows a future as an arsonist.
On Martha's Vineyard, Drew is thrown into an affluent, party-loving <a href="African-American">black</a> society that congregates on a beach known as the "Inkwell". The visit is also the occasion of some bitter family strife. Drew's Aunt Frances (<a href="Vanessa%20Bell%20Calloway">Vanessa Bell Calloway</a>) and her husband, Spencer (<a href="Glynn%20Turman">Glynn Turman</a>), are <a href="Conservatism">conservative</a>s whose walls are plastered with pictures of <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican</a> dignitaries such as <a href="Barry%20Goldwater">Barry Goldwater</a> and <a href="Ronald%20Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a> (who they keep saying will become president someday). Kenny, a former <a href="Black%20Panther%20Party">Black Panther</a>, and Spencer argue furiously about racial issues.
"The Inkwell" follows Drew's bumbling pursuit of the insufferably snooty Lauren (<a href="Jada%20Pinkett%20Smith">Jada Pinkett</a>). He also befriends Heather (<a href="Adrienne-Joi%20Johnson">Adrienne-Joi Johnson</a>), a young woman whose husband, Harold (<a href="Morris%20Chestnut">Morris Chestnut</a>), is a faithless louse. The movie comes to an end on the <a href="Independence%20Day%20%28United%20States%29">Fourth of July</a>, when the <a href="United%20States%20Bicentennial">Bicentennial</a> fireworks end up symbolizing not just <a href="United%20States">America's</a> 200th birthday but Drew finally having sex with Heather.
Production.
For the 20th anniversary of the film, the cast reunited with writer/filmmaker Lathleen Ade-Brown for "<a href="Essence%20%28magazine%29">Essence</a>" where Larenz Tate spoke about the casting process. He told the magazine "Matty Rich was holding auditions in LA. Jada [Pinkett Smith] was already cast in the role [as Lauren] and I remember her calling me, saying, ‘You got to do this movie!’ In fact, she was saying, ‘Listen, let’s meet up and rehearse because they are going to want me to read with you, so let’s rehearse, so you totally land it!’ I told her, ‘I’m going to rip that role! No need to rehearse, you just keep up with me and we just play off each other.’ She says. ‘I got you, let’s do it!’ I go in the audition and we really just lit up the room, then I had to audition solo. They didn't know what to expect considering I just did Menace II Society playing O-Dawg, a completely street person. So that impressed them and they offered me the part."
Reception.
"The Inkwell" was poorly received by critics. It holds a rating of 22% on <a href="Rotten%20Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> based on 9 reviews. It has since become a <a href="cult%20classic">cult classic</a>.
